author: Tim Spark
title: Hale adds toughness at Salisbury
text:
Former Bowie soccer star adapts to position change at Liberty (Tim Sparks) 
Hale is confident that the 2015 Sea Gulls will show improvement after going 7-4 and the winning the Eastern College Athletic Conference South Atlantic Bowl against Albright College last November. 
"I think we're more competitive," said Hale, who plans to follow his father's lead and become an officer in the Air Force. "We have some key players back. Overall, we're older now. Coach Wood has talked about maturity. We know a lot more football (this year) and coaches can be more detail-oriented." 
With much expected from Hale this season, the pressure will be high. But that seems unlikely to affect Hale, given his competitive fire. He want to win so badly -- at everything -- that his friends won't even play video games with him anymore. 
His distaste for losing complements his physical gifts and cerebral approach. 
"I'm good in coverage," Hale said. "A lot of people don't regard safeties as cover guys, but it's what I do well. I'm a student of the game. I know the game. I'm tough, physical, fearless. I like to go out there, have fun and be fearless." 
Not surprisingly, Hale wants to be remembered for his toughness, a quality that always leaves an impression on coaches. While his impact at Salisbury may be minimized by his short tenure there, it appears that he has already begun leaving his mark. 
"I am extremely pleased to have Mike as a member of our team," Wood said. "He is a winner and true competitor. He has instilled leadership and serves as a mentor for our program."
